repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Public Service Performance
            Enhancement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Service Performance
            Enhancement Project for Uganda received a moderately
            unsatisfactory development outcome with substantial risk to
            development outcome. The Bank received a moderately
            unsatisfactory performance rating while the Borrowers
            performance was deemed unsatisfactory. Two restructurings
            took place during this project. The first restructuring
            limited component 2 to three main activities, including (i)
            establishment of a Civil Service College (CSC); (ii)
            provision of targeted training and research in strategic
            areas of the growth agenda; and (iii) equip top public
            service managers with leadership skills, b. reducing the
            Credit amount and, c. extending the closing date by 2 years.
            The second restructuring pushed the closing date back one
            more year. There were six key lessons taken from this
            project and are as follows: (1) A first lesson learned is
            the importance of investing time and effort in aligning and
            securing both political and technical support for the life
            of the project. (2) A second lesson learned is that
            appropriate monitoring and evaluation mechanisms are
            required to proactively track the impacts of reforms. (3) A
            third lesson learned is the importance of focusing on
            context and process in project design, taking into account
            political economy factors as well as existing and potential
            capacity constraints. (4) A fourth lesson learned is the
            need for flexible and iterative approaches in project
            implementation. (5) A fifth lesson learned is the importance
            of adequate leadership, capacity, and authority in the
            implementing agency. (6) A sixth lesson learned is that
            clear and simple implementation arrangements are essential
            to smooth implementation during the life of a project and to
            the eventual achievement of project objectives.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Public Service Performance
            Enhancement Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
A Records and Archives Center will be
            built to provide a safe repository for government records as
            one of the components of the Uganda Public Service
            Performance Enhancement Program (UPSPEP). This environmental
            impact assessment addresses negative environmental impacts
            associated with this component. Negative impacts include
            conversion of a residential site for public use; improper
            management of excavated or filled soil leading to dust
            plumes that affect air quality; loose soil in storm water
            clogging adjacent drains; traffic congestion; generation of
            demolition waste; stripped vegetation and land overburdened
            from site leveling operations; loss of trees; improper waste
            disposal; incineration of office waste leading to air
            pollution if it is not operated according to
            manufacturer's specifications or improperly maintained;
            dust; and noise from electricity generators. Impact
            abatement measures that are recommended include on-site
            waste management practices like document incineration;
            having workers protect against occupational safety risks
            such as exposure to noise, dust, and body injuries by using
            safety latches, for example; having professional engineers
            and architects supervise construction; replanting with low
            maintenance native species and marking uncut trees for
            protection; suppressing dust with water spraying and issuing
            dust masks to workers; restricting construction activities
            during the daytime; providing silencers for equipment to
            control noise; transporting lubricants and fuels in
            appropriate containers such as sealed drums; transporting
            materials during off-peak hours; limiting stockpiling to
            areas away from drains; placing low beams around piles and
            covering open piles; properly storing hazardous chemicals;
            preparing a site waste management plan; and disposing of
            un-reusable construction waste at an approved landfill.

docna.cdata!:
Environmental impact statement for proposed
            records and archives center
